newsitem.title: GERMANY: German coffee roaster may lose sales in 1997.
newsitem.headline: German coffee roaster may lose sales in 1997.

text.p: German coffee roaster J.J. Darboven told a news conference on Tuesday sales volumes in 1997 may be curtailed by necessary retail price rises.
The company would keep unchanged the origin mix in its high quality blends even if this was causing additional costs.
"We will use the same green coffees as ever, we'd rather sell less coffee than compromise on quality," group chairman Albert Darboven said.

The family-owned group sold 25,688 tonnes of roasted coffee in 1996, up from 24,000 in 1995, but Darboven said earnings had been unsatisfactory amid a decline in retail prices, but he would not elaborate.

Darboven, along with most German roasters, is set to raise prices by 1.50 marks per 0.5 kg as of March 10, in a bid to pass on dramatically higher raw materials costs and an unfavourable mark/dollar ratio.
Further price increases have not been ruled out.
The 1996 German coffee market average was 7.01 marks, with Darboven's products some 0.47 marks more expensive.
Darboven has an estimated market share of eight to nine percent in Germany from sales in supermarkets, tied outlets in some regions, as well as hotels, canteens and airlines.
Within the total, sales to supermarkets rose by 8.3 percent to 13,012 tonnes while sales to users outside private households rose by five percent to 3,950 tonnes.
Darboven has a 10 percent share in this sector, which it said generated higher intrinsic revenue but was hit by a decline in tourism and slimmer business expense accounts.

International group manager Luc de Vries said the company would grow in eastern Europe, where an increase in tourism generated demand for its coffee and preparation systems. --Vera Eckert, Hamburg newsroom, +49-40-41903275
